This is by no means the perfect game. There are flaws, there are bugs, I regularly get dropped by the server. There are trolls online, both intentionally trolling and unintentionally (if you don't know what offside is, read up on it before playing!) But what it does have going for it is sheer fun factor.

If you remember Sensible Soccer, WoSO is in a similar vein, from the pixel graphics to sharing more than a little in common with Sensible World of Soccer's name. But as the telling difference in the name reveals, WoSO is an online game. You control just one player, with the other players on your team controlled by other humans (yay) or the AI (boo). And it's this multiplayer element that is at the heart of WoS's fun factor. As in real life football, playing as a team is essential; good positioning is worth a lot and a team playing as a unit can still beat a team full of better players who are all playing for themselves. It can be really satisfying when your team puts together a string of neat passes culminating in a goal, or when you've spent 90 minutes defending resolutely only to nick a 1-0 victory in the dying moments on the counter.

Controls are relatively simple; movement is via mouse (run to the cursor a la diablo), gamepad or keyboard (not a good option IMO). I'm using a controller where you have 3 buttons that I'd call shoot" "lob" and "pass". The controls are not well explained

That's a good thing, and it feels really rewarding when you play the game. It's a free game that isn't at all pay to win. You'll get into it fast. The only issue is that the game at times can lag if you select a match on a high pink server. I've found servers every time I go into the game as low as 24 ping, and been able to play on this without issue. The developer is working on this issue and working to add other features to the game. Give this game a try, and then talk your friends into it. Even the ones who are not fans of this sport.

reviewText:
Playing this game is like playing an unfinished product. Mainly because it is one.
With my experience, the gameplay is the same - either too balanced, or too unbalanced. What do I mean?

Well, this game would have been tons more fun if you could upgrade your player to specific stats, so training rooms and teams could require a specific level cap (so it isn't too unbalanced).This would create strategy (that is missing from the game) and complexity, trying out new styles and possibly being a fun experience. However, we settle for this - a really basic unfinished product where every character plays the exact same.

When in matches, unless you're teamed up with people who aren't selfish ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, you'll find that the only person defending is your keeper (who is CPU controlled), every teammate ever would just act like a hero and come up forth, ignoring basic offside rules, ultimately screwing up the team. This could be countered by adding a ratings system based on the player's performance in his positon, so these ratings stick to a player after each game so people could know how much of a ♥♥♥♥ he is. But I'm not here trying to convince the devs to put a little bit more balance (or fun complex unbalance) to the game even though it would be great. I'm here to advise you whether this game is worth it or not.

In conclusion, this game is an unsuccessful attempt at a minimum viable product, every player plays the same, basic physics and rules aren't that well implemented, slide tackles are too op (since there isn't any fouls) so you find everybody just lunging at each other at the speed of light, and the whole experience is just the same every time. This game neither showcases the random exciting nature of the real sport, nor does it showcase the players' skills. And that would be a good thing, if the game was just a simple fun experience, but it definitely isn't one. I'd advise the devs to take what they've learned from this failed attempt and focus on improving on the core formula, since this could be a great title, until then - I wouldn't recommend this title.

Overall Review: 7.5/10

OverviewThis game is great. The servers have a bad history, but after a bit the creators got new servers up and running and logins are working flawlessly. The person making this game is a previous developer of Net Soccer, and it shows. The UI is the most painful thing in this game, expecially when it was back when the servers were trashy, but since the game just went up from greenlight it's okay to have some inconvience riddled inside.

GameplayThe controls are, if not exactly a replica of, a close copy of Net Soccer, which controls very well. I like the ball lob mechanic the most, and the slide tackle works very well. I've never played Outdoor Soccer(Football), but these seem very nice for the game. The AI controlled players are very well created too, I'm honestly suprised at how well they preform. You can call to them to pass the ball to you, but I wish it made some notification so that you could notify other players as well.

Community & Online PlayThe community isn't that great according to some people, but I haven't seen one person that is too rude or plain annoying yet. The team system is well made too, You can make your own custom jerseys, which look actually nice in game. The organised matches are the bread and butter of this game and I love to play in them. With good communication you can make great plays and tactics, and its overall very well done.

ConclusionOverall I think this game could DEFINITELY use some changes over time, but for only 3 days on steam, it looks amazing and plays very well. The reason for my lower score is that the UI needs some serious reworking to be usable. He possibly needs to find some community members to help with that, most of them would know how it should be done to fit to the player, considering they are the community.

reviewText:
Despite the lack of proper UI, this game is ADDICTIVE and FUN as hell! Controls are simple, yet the game has a lot of depth, which you uncover as you keep playing. What's best is that there are no statistics like speed, stamina, shooting, or what have you. It's all about your SKILL!

Game provides several control schemes: mouse only, mouse + keyboard, and controller only. My favorite is mouse only. It's very well done! It solves the traditional problem of keyboard control -- being able to run only in 8 directions. Mouse control gives you full precision of your passes, shots, and movement.

You will occasionally meet a griefer, but overall the community is nice. I highly recommend playing with as few players as possible to maximize your time on the ball; you will need some practice to become a respectable footballer.  I had some sick 3v3s and 4v4s last night! Boy what is fun!

With the addition of tutorial in the last version, it's now easy to pick up basic controls and concepts. The dev seems to be churning out updates constantly. That's always a good sign!

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

reviewText: This game is extremely simple, which is usually not a bad thing. Sadly, this game also feels very uninspired. From the art style to the sound design, it is quite clear that essentially every aspect of this game was simply not crafted with the love and care and attention that some of the great game developers such as Valve have. I feel like the dullness of the game cannot even be attributed to a potential budgetary issue the developers may have had. They could have certainly spiced this game up if they had tried or cared to try. Either way, it is a very simple game that virtually any PC could run, so it does have that going for it. There seemed to be a decent, albeit small, chunk of people playing. (I played for just over five minutes, so take what I say with a grain of salt, if you must.) If they added achievements or in-game voice chat, this game would have a better chance, but I fear it'll die off in no time. :/ I suppose it's worth playing if you're bored or feeling like trying something new. After all, it is free... It would be a crime to charge actual money for this game... Speaking of which, I did not notice any offers for micro-transactions, which is also a good thing for this particular game. Ah, I digress. Play it at your liesure, but don't expect too much.
